"I want to film a documentary on Ryuichi Sakamoto for a French television program." In 1983, director Elizabeth Lennard visited Sakamoto in Berlin—where he was attending a David Sylvian recording session—to make this proposal. In May 1984, just as Sakamoto began work on his fourth solo album, *Ongaku Zukan*, filming took place in Tokyo over a brief span of only one week. The five-member French crew, led by Lennard, captured a vivid record of Japan, the city of Tokyo, and the musician Ryuichi Sakamoto.

Following its 1985 completion and French TV broadcast, the film screened at international festivals in Rotterdam, Locarno, and São Paulo. In Japan, it premiered at the inaugural Tokyo International Film Festival on June 9th of that year. While the subsequent VHS and DVD releases were long out of print and difficult to obtain, the original 16mm film was recently discovered in a warehouse and has been digitally restored.

Within its 60-minute runtime, the film captures a 30-something Sakamoto in the studio and in interviews, discussing his upbringing, values, musical philosophy, and culture. It also features footage from Nagisa Oshima’s *Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence* (1983), YMO’s "scatter" concerts, and music videos, while projecting the vibrant energy of 1980s Tokyo—from the Shibuya Scramble to Shinjuku Alta—onto the screen. This legendary documentary, an immersion into the "Sounds of Tokyo" as seen through Sakamoto’s eyes and portrait, finally makes its theatrical debut after nearly 40 years.

title:「ドキュメンタリー・フィードバック」シリーズより:
"The ethical dimensions of documentary filmmaking (and, to an extent, ethics in cinema as a whole) are themes that have generated endless debate and critical discussion. As a work that foregrounds the inherent ethical questions and power dynamics of documentary filmmaking and demonstrates a singular approach to addressing them, we present a screening of William Greaves's *Symbiopsychotaxiplasm: Take One*. Though the film remained unreleased theatrically for many years, its screening at the 1992 Sundance Film Festival led to its distribution through the efforts of Steven Soderbergh and others. Drawing on philosopher Arthur F. Bentley’s concept of "symbiopsychotaxiplasm"—the relationship between humans and their environment—the film employs split screens to create a multi-layered portrait of a film production being shot improvisationally in Central Park.
tmdb:126863: A representative work of "structural film" that uses the early comedy *Tom, Tom, the Piper's Son* (1905)—which depicted the chaos of a festive crowd—as source material for re-photography. title:構造映画作品集: "Structural Film," a concept proposed by film critic P. title:デイヴィッド・ブルックス作品集: Appointed executive director of the Film-Makers’ Cooperative (founded by Jonas Mekas) at the age of 18, David Brooks (1944–1969) was a central figure in the New York underground film scene, producing brilliant works until his death at the young age of 24. title:ロン・ライス作品集（1）: Ron Rice (1935–1964) passed away at the young age of 29, yet he is regarded as one of the most pivotal figures of 1960s underground cinema for his singular originality. title:マリー・メンケン／マージョリー・ケラー作品集: Marie Menken (1910–1970) was a key figure of the New York underground who exerted a profound influence on the style of Jonas Mekas. title:アンソロジー・フィルムアーカイブスの創設者たち: This program features works by Jonas Mekas (1922–2019), Peter Kubelka (1934–), Stan Brakhage (1933–2003), and James Broughton (1913–1999)—key figures who played a central role in the founding of Anthology Film Archives—as well as Marjorie Keller’s *The Fallen World* (1983), which features P. Adams Sitney (1944–2025).
title:「オーディオビジュアル・フィードバック」シリーズより: "The artists presented here move beyond unidirectional flows of information and expression to experiment with circular, reflective, or multidirectional configurations of images, sounds, and ideas, while demonstrating how different technologies generate opportunities for diverse variations, analyses, and philosophical or aesthetic self-reflection." title:抽象アニメーション作品集: This program provides an overview ranging from the works of visual music pioneers Oskar Fischinger (1900–1967) and Mary Ellen Bute (1906–1983) to 1960s American experimental animation—including Robert Breer’s (1926–2011) *Breathing* (1963) and James Whitney’s (1921–1982) *Lapis* (1966)—and through to *Frank Film* (1973), the first autobiographical work to win the Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film. tmdb:435421: The 23rd work in Stan Brakhage’s (1933–2003) 8mm silent “Song” series, this film was created as a direct response to the Vietnam War. title:A DOCUMENTARY FILM OF LOSTAGE -ひかり:
What is life? What does it mean to make a living through music? What, exactly, is a rock band?

LOSTAGE is a three-piece rock band based in Nara that continues to tour live houses across Japan. Their work is never reflected in the hit charts—they deliberately chose a path outside of major distribution and sales channels. Yet, every one of their releases has sold over 5,500 copies, and their back catalog continues to be repressed, with sales figures steadily climbing to this day.

Now in their 40s, they are a rare active band with a devoted following that transcends age and gender, recently completing a sold-out 47-prefecture tour and a successful solo performance at the Hibiya Open-Air Concert Hall. Now in their 25th year, the three members have each built families in Nara and run community-based businesses, continuing their musical activities as a direct extension of their daily lives.

Once expected to "make it big" as a rock band, they even experienced a major label debut. However, with 2011 serving as a turning point, they have navigated a path of twists and turns, buffeted by the whims of reality.

While "deified" by countless fellow musicians, the three members remain firmly grounded in their daily lives. This intimate documentary explores the mystery and allure of LOSTAGE in their truest form—a band that continues to pursue a dream-like existence while remaining rooted in the reality of home and family.

title:安楽死特区:
What if a "Euthanasia Bill" were passed in Japan?

Following the passage of the bill in the Diet, a facility named "Hitorishizuka" is established as a National Strategic Special Zone. Designed for those seeking euthanasia to reside and receive care, the facility becomes a lightning rod for controversy at the intersection of ethics and politics.

Shotaro Sako (Katsuya Maiguma), a rapper suffering from an incurable disease with no hope of recovery, continues to weave words together, finding salvation in hip-hop even as his condition worsens. He lives with Ayumi Fujioka (Ayaka Onishi), a journalist he met in Tibet. Despite Shotaro being given only six months to live, the two remain opposed to euthanasia and enter "Hitorishizuka" with the intent of exposing the reality of the special zone from the inside.

The facility is home to various residents, each with their own story: Ikeda (Mitsuru Hirata), who is suffering from terminal cancer, and his wife Tamami (Mariko Tsutsui); and Shinya (Kimiko Yo), a former manzai comedian with dementia who wishes to die before she completely loses her sense of self.

As Shotaro’s physical strength rapidly declines and even speaking becomes a struggle, he abruptly changes his mind without consulting Ayumi, stating, "I want euthanasia." Ayumi is forced to confront the weight of life and death as she encounters the convictions of the specialized doctors—including Ikeda’s physician Torii (Eiji Okuda) and Shotaro’s physicians Ogata (Masaya Kato) and Miura (Yuka Itaya).
